abstract:
The River Bonding Tool (RBT) is a set of GIS tools designed to analyze river channels within ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software. It uses high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs), which can be obtained from airborne remote sensing like LiDAR or ground surveys. The tool calculates various metrics at regular intervals along the length of a river site, allowing users to assess the characteristics of the channel.

The RBT provides several important output values: mean, standard deviation, and coefficient of variation for each profile metric; filtered means, standard deviations, and coefficients of variation for selected profile intervals; and all profile values with their corresponding interval distances downstream from the site's top.

Filtering is an essential part of this method. It removes any outlier values that are more than a set number of standard deviations away from the population mean. This helps to exclude irrelevant data and ensures accurate representation of the river channel's characteristics. For CHaMP 2011 data, the filtering threshold was set at 4 standard deviations.

In summary, the RBT is a valuable tool for assessing river channels using high-resolution DEMs. It provides comprehensive metrics and allows users to filter out outlier values, ensuring accurate analysis of the data. This information is crucial for monitoring and understanding the complexities of river systems, addressing issues related to water resource management, flood risk assessment, and environmental conservation.
description:
The River Buffer Tool (RBT) is a collection of GIS applications integrated within ESRI's ArcGIS Desktop software. This tool is specifically designed for processing and analyzing river channels using high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). RBT users can acquire DEMs through various sources, including airborne remote sensing techniques like LiDAR or ground-based topographic surveys.

The profile metrics are calculated along the entire length of the site at customizable intervals. For instance, in the 2011 CHaMP dataset, each interval measured 0.5m. Each metric consists of several output values:

1. Mean: Represents the average value for all profile metrics.
2. Standard deviation (SD): Measures the dispersion or variation from the mean for all profile metrics.
3. Coefficient of variation (CV): Represents the SD as a percentage of the mean for all profile metrics.
4. Filtered mean: Reports the mean for a selected subset of profile intervals.
5. Filtered standard deviation: Provides the SD for the chosen subset of profile intervals.
6. Filtered coefficient of variation: Presents the CV for the specified subset of profile intervals.
7. All profile values with their corresponding cumulative interval distance: Reveals the progression of all profile values along the site, measured in downstream distances from the top of the site.

The filtered metrics represent the same statistical analysis but only for a defined subset of the profile intervals. Filtering eliminates any data points that deviate more than a predetermined threshold (in 2011 CHaMP, set at 4 standard deviations) from the population mean. This process aims to exclude outliers from the metrics for improved accuracy and reliability in river channel analysis. The CHaMP - Topographic Point Collection Methods documentation provides further insight into data collection methods used for this calculation.
